title: States Sue SEC to Kill Broker Conduct Rule
text:
Text size

Photograph by Andrew Harrer/Bloomberg

Seven states and the District of Columbia have sued the Securities and Exchange Commission to overturn an investment-advice rule that is meant to overhaul how brokers work with their clients but that the plaintiffs claim is too weak.

So reports InvestmentNews. Attorneys general for the states of New York, California, Connecticut, Delaware, Maine, New Mexico and Oregon filed the lawsuit Monday in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York. SEC Chairman Jay Clayton is also named in the suit.

The lawsuit seeks to vacate the final rule, which was issued in June after a 3-1 vote by commissioners, and permanently prevent its implementation, which is scheduled for the end of June 2020.
description: Seven states and D/C/ claim Regulation Best Interest undermines critical consumer protections for retail investors.
